topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53c370086368726949470000#post_53c370086368726949470000
I'm not saying that humans are bad, rather that lack of self preservation is fundamentally self destructive.

Also the crux in your point is that the belief any and all life must be competitive with other members of the same species.  The problem with this is that hypothetically speaking imagine if the whole world was united under one country that everyone accepted instead of how we have 196 countries.  All that money we put towards war would instead be used towards development and other governmental departments.  What I mean by this is that imagine if instead of spending a trillion dollars a year towards our military we instead used that trillion dollars towards NASA, education and other civilian departments?

In other words the crux of your argument is that your point relies on the belief that any and all civilizations must operate 100% like ours without any sort of deviance.  The problem with this is that if sapience evolves in a herbivore species that is non-competitive would develop a non-competitive cooperative society instead and thus drastically reduce the probability of self destruction.

This belief further falls apart even on our own planet in that there's countries and cultures where cooperation is viewed as more important than competition.

In other words your theory only works towards either carnivorous/omnivorous species and only in cultures in which competition is more important culturally than cooperation.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53c3723c636872682b970000#post_53c3723c636872682b970000
Cooperation is a fine and good thing, but competition is what drives innovation. Hell, that's not just how culture and science advances its how natural selection itself works. No, its not nice or good or pretty, but its how life works.

As evolved life forms we bare the scars of our upbringing. Its in our lusts, our fears, our mistrusts and our ambitions.

Even herbivorous species can be shockingly violent towards each other. Vegetarianism is not a guarantee of peacefulness.

You claim there are countries and cultures that value cooperation over competition. Care to name them? Go through their histories? Really get into their culture?

We're not built for cooperation on anything other than a micro level. Loyalty to family and tribe because those are the ones we see and interact with every day, that's what gets hardwired into our genes. We had to learn how to not be bastards, and we've come a long fucking way baby.

*EDIT:* Not that I'm not enjoying this debate but I'll have to get back to you on the subject in the morning. I need sleep.

topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53c376b96368726eee490000#post_53c376b96368726eee490000
The problem is you're quoting a lot about how "natural selection" works, but keep in mind that natural selection doesn't just pertain to survival of the fittest, but things like genetic pressure or so forth and such.  What I mean by this is that there is more to evolution than just survival of the fittest.  The last couple of hundred years humans have evolved surprisingly fast not cause of natural selection, but because of cultural pressure on the genepool shaping which genes become widespread and which die out.  To put it bluntly we've evolved beyond natural selection and culture is playing a much larger part towards our evolution as a species now instead.

On the micro scale let's say in a culture it's no longer considered culturally acceptable for a person to be naturally violent and go around beating the shit out of anyone that talks back to them; that will have a effect on humans evolution in that the genes that promote violence will be "pushed" out of the genepool.

What is essentially happening with human evolution is that on a macro scale traits that promote culturally unacceptable behavior are being pushed out of the genepool.

"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53c37abe6368727fb3ed0000#post_53c37abe6368727fb3ed0000
[bq="SeraphimDawn"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53c379436368726ff7d30000#post_53c379436368726ff7d30000
Mankind does not need violence to be malicious. Violence might be breed out, but malice unfortunately stays. Count me as one of those who would not allow society to judge on who we are. We as individuals, pick our paths.[/bq]
Violence is kind of rapidly going away at this point.  Since the collapse of the soviet union wars have drastically dropped.  While this is more of a cultural thing it does point towards say in forty years or so that our great grandkids will probably think of anyone who supports war or violence as loonies that need psychiatric help.

2050 is probably going to be like,
"You know; sometimes war is a good thing"
(everyone immediately stops what they're doing and stares at the person who said it)
"(one person whispering to another) ~Hey can you call a psychologist?  We have a loon on the loose.~

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53c37cf96368724ce7e10000#post_53c37cf96368724ce7e10000
[bq="SeraphimDawn"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53c37c606368727029100000#post_53c37c606368727029100000
And you know what happens when a large group of people who learn they share the same sentiment gather up? They may start shit out of impulse and pleasure.

As long as malice and boredom stays in any shape or form, there will never be peace.[/bq]
I didn't say there will ever be world peace, rather war will become a extremely rare occurrence that only happens once in a blue moon.

In fifty or so years sure there will still be wars, but we're talking only one or two wars every decade or so.

Right now there's only ten wars going on.  Right now afghanistan is finally calming down(the death toll is still high, but less than last year), the mexican drug war is calming down and the egypt revolution crisis is calming down.
